title: Visualizing Data
code: energy %>%    tidyplot(x = power) %>%    add_histogram() energy %>%    tidyplot(x = power) %>%    add_density_curve() energy %>%    tidyplot(x = power) %>%    add_density_histogram() %>%    add_density_curve() # multiple distributions  energy %>%    tidyplot(x = energy_type, y = power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_violin() energy %>%    tidyplot(x = energy_type, y = power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_jitter(jitter_width = 0.8, alpha = 0.3) energy %>%    tidyplot(x = energy_type, y = power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_violin() %>%    add_jitter(jitter_width = 0.8, alpha = 0.3)

title: Visualizing Data
code: # themes  p4 <-    energy %>%    tidyplot(year, power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_barstack_absolute()  p4 p4 %>% theme_minimal_y() p4 %>% theme_ggplot2() # proportions  energy %>%    tidyplot(year, power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_barstack_absolute() energy %>%    tidyplot(year, power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_barstack_relative() energy %>%    dplyr::filter(year %in% c(2005, 2010, 2015, 2020)) %>%    tidyplot(y = power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_pie() %>%    split_plot(by = year) energy %>%    dplyr::filter(year %in% c(2005, 2010, 2015, 2020)) %>%    tidyplot(y = power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_donut() %>%    split_plot(by = year) # pie and donut  animals %>%    tidyplot(y = weight, color = family) %>%    add_pie() animals %>%    tidyplot(y = weight, color = family) %>%    add_donut() animals %>%    tidyplot(color = family) %>%    add_pie() animals %>%    tidyplot(color = family) %>%    add_donut() # add_barstack_absolute  animals %>%    tidyplot(color = family) %>%    add_barstack_absolute() animals %>%    tidyplot(x = diet, color = family) %>%    add_barstack_absolute() ## with y supplied  animals %>%    tidyplot(y = speed, color = family) %>%    add_barstack_absolute() animals %>%    tidyplot(x = diet, y = speed, color = family) %>%    add_barstack_absolute() # add_barstack_absolute  animals %>%    tidyplot(color = family) %>%    add_barstack_relative() animals %>%    tidyplot(x = diet, color = family) %>%    add_barstack_relative() animals %>%    tidyplot(x = diet, color = family) %>%    add_barstack_absolute(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_areastack_absolute() ## with y supplied  animals %>%    tidyplot(x = diet, y = speed, color = family) %>%    add_barstack_absolute(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_areastack_absolute() animals %>%    tidyplot(y = speed, color = family) %>%    add_barstack_relative() animals %>%    tidyplot(x = diet, y = speed, color = family) %>%    add_barstack_relative() # curves  energy_week %>%    tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_line() %>%    remove_padding() energy_week %>%    tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_area(alpha = 0.3) energy_week %>%    tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_areastack_absolute() energy_week %>%    tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_areastack_relative() ###  energy %>%    tidyplot(year, power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_barstack_absolute() energy %>%    tidyplot(year, power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_barstack_relative() new_colors <- c("Fossil" = "grey",                "Nuclear" = "#F6C54D",                "Renewable" = "#4FAE62",                "Other" = "#C02D45")  energy %>%    dplyr::filter(year %in% c(2005, 2010, 2015, 2020)) %>%    tidyplot(y = power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_pie() %>%    adjust_colors(new_colors = new_colors) %>%    split_plot(by = year) energy %>%    dplyr::filter(year %in% c(2005, 2010, 2015, 2020)) %>%    tidyplot(y = power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_donut() %>%    adjust_colors(new_colors = new_colors) %>%     split_plot(by = year) energy %>%    dplyr::filter(year %in% c(2005, 2010, 2015, 2020)) %>%    tidyplot(x = year, y = power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_sum_line(dodge_width = 0) %>%   add_sum_dot(dodge_width = 0) %>%    adjust_colors(new_colors = new_colors) energy %>%    tidyplot(x = year, y = power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_areastack_absolute() %>%    adjust_colors(new_colors = new_colors) energy %>%    tidyplot(x = year, y = power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_areastack_absolute() energy %>%    dplyr::filter(year %in% c(2005, 2010, 2015, 2020)) %>%    tidyplot(x = year, y = power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_areastack_relative() %>%    adjust_colors(new_colors = new_colors) energy_week %>%    tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_sum_line() %>%   adjust_colors(new_colors = new_colors) %>%    remove_padding() energy_week %>%    dplyr::summarise(power = sum(power), .by = c(date, energy_type)) %>%    tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_area(alpha = 0.3) %>%    adjust_colors(new_colors = new_colors) energy_week %>%    tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_areastack_absolute() %>%    adjust_colors(new_colors = new_colors) energy_week %>%   tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_type) %>%    add_areastack_relative() %>%    adjust_colors(new_colors = new_colors)

title: Visualizing Data
code: study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_ci95() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score) %>%    add_ci95_ribbon() %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score) %>%    add_ci95_ribbon() %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_jitter() %>%    adjust_colors("orange")

title: Visualizing Data
code: energy_week %>%    tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_line() %>%    remove_padding() energy_week %>%    tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_area(alpha = 0.3) energy_week %>%    tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_source) %>%    add_points()

title: tidyplots
text: tidyplots aims delivering ready--publish plots, eliminating cumbersome formatting tasks. tidyplots uses pipe %>% (instead + like ggplot2) build plots. way can seamlessly pipe plot. example, coming fram data wrangeling pipeline can generate plot directly pipe save_plot(). can also call save_plot() render_plot() middle pipeline output intermediate results. tidyplots tries reduce complexity ggplot2 choosing sensible defaults. However, take detailed control via ... argument function. need add plain ggplot2 code, can using add() function, preserve tidyplots pipeline. plots absolute dimensions default, defined “mm”. dimensions refer plotting area, entire plot, thus ensuring consistent lengths x y axes. dimension can changed width height parameters, either creating plot tidyplot() later adjust_size(). want restore ggplot2 behavior plot automatically takes available space, set width height NA. tidyplots allows split plots subplots variable choice, similar ggplot2::facet_wrap(). However, split_plot() provides consistent look allows distribute subplots across multiple pages. color fill always mapped variable. However, can still one following: (1) reduce opacity fill using alpha saturation arguments, (2) set color fill constant hex color within add_ function, (3) set color fill NA within add_ function prevent displayed.

title: tidyplots
text: data plotted needs tidy sense (1) variable must column, (2) observation must row (3) value must cell. learn tidy data, look excellent book R Data Science. create plot, start tidyplot() function. pipe add_ functions, adjust_ functions, theme_ functions remove_ functions, preferably order. split_plot() must last sequence can followed save_plot().

what: Standing on the shoulders of giants
title: tidyplots
code: ggplot2 and the rest of the tidyverse by Hadley Wickham et al. patchwork by Thomas Lin Pedersen ggpubr by Alboukadel Kassambara ggrastr by Evan Biederstedt ggrepel by Kamil Slowikowski

title: tidyplots
code: library(tidyplots) animals %>%   tidyplot(family, size, color = family) %>%    add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_error() %>%    add_points() %>%    adjust_labels(family, sort_by = size) study %>%   tidyplot(treatment, score, color = treatment) %>%   add_range() %>%    add_points() study %>%   tidyplot(treatment, score) %>%   add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%   add_error() %>%   add_points() %>%   add_mean_line() study %>%   tidyplot(treatment, score) %>%   add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%   add_error() %>%   add_points() %>%   add_line(group = participant, dodge_width = 0) study %>%   tidyplot(group, score, color = dose) %>%   add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%   add_error() %>%   add_jitter() p1 <-    study %>%   tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%   add_mean_dash() %>%   add_error() %>%   add_jitter() p1 p2 <-    study %>%   tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%   add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%   add_error() %>%   add_jitter() p2 study %>%   tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%   add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%   add_error() %>%   add_jitter(style = "confetti") # testing adjust_colors() adjust_labels() split_plot() interference # "split" always after "adjust" # "adjust_color()" always after "adjust_labels()"  # providing less or more colors, not a problem new_colors <-   c("A" = "#B0B1B3",     "B" = "#F18823",     "C" = "#E23130",     "D" = "#1D5D83")  # providing less names, not a problem. Providing more names -> Error new_names <-   c("A" = "Regime A",     "B" = "Regime B",     "C" = "Regime C",     "D" = "Regime D")  p2 %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_order = c("C")) %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) p2 %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_order = c("C")) p2 %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_names = new_names) %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) p2 %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_names = new_names) # providing more colors, not a problem. Providing less colors -> Error new_colors <-   c("#B0B1B3",     "#F18823",     "#E23130",     "#1D5D83")  p2 %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_order = c("C")) %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) p2 %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_order = c("C")) p2 %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_names = new_names) %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) p2 %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_names = new_names) # during split plot, single subplots might only have NA for certain categories # this has been fixed apparently by using drop = FALSE in   # adjusting axis limits  p1 %>%   adjust_y_axis(limits = c(-20, 60)) # x--y plots   p3 <-    animals %>%    tidyplot(x = weight, y = size, color = number_of_legs) %>%    add_points(style = "confetti") %>%    add_points(style = "confetti", data = filter_rows(size > 300), color = "red") %>%    add_text(data = max_rows(weight, n = 3), var = animal, color = "black")    p3 p3 %>% add_reference_lines(x = c(4000), y = c(200, 350)) # labels of out of bounds animals still appear p3 %>%   adjust_y_axis(limits = c(0, 600)) %>%    adjust_x_axis(limits = c(0, 1000)) energy_week %>%   tidyplot(date, power, color = energy_type) %>%   add_mean_line() %>%   adjust_y_axis(limits = c(1000, 5000)) %>%    remove_padding() # adding titles and captions  p2 %>% add_title("My fancy long title") p2 %>% add_caption("Here goes the fine print") # adjusting axis titles  p2 %>% adjust_x_axis("My x axis title") p2 %>% adjust_y_axis("My y axis title") # adjusting legend  p2 %>% adjust_legend(title = "My legend title") p2 %>% adjust_legend(title = "My legend title", position = "top") # plotmath expressions  p2 %>% add_title(title = "$E==m*c^{2}~H[2]*O$") p2 %>% add_caption(caption = "$E==m*c^{2}~H[2]*O$") p2 %>% adjust_legend(title = "$E==m*c^{2}~H[2]*O$") p2 %>% adjust_x_axis(title = "$Domino~E==m*c^{2}$") p2 %>% adjust_y_axis(title = "$Domino~E==m*c^{2}$") new_names <-   c("A" = "$TNF*alpha$",     "B" = "$IFN*gamma$",     "C" = "plain text",     "D" = "$H[2]*O$")  p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_names = new_names) # adjust labels  new_names <-   c("A" = "Regime A",     "B" = "Regime B",     "C" = "Regime C",     "D" = "Regime D")  p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_names = new_names) p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_names = new_names) %>% adjust_x_axis(rotate_labels = TRUE) p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_names = new_names, sort_by = score) p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_names = new_names, reverse = TRUE) new_order <-    c("D", "C")  p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, new_order = new_order) p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, sort_by = score) p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment, reverse = TRUE) p2 %>% adjust_labels(treatment) # adjust colors  new_colors <-   c("A" = "#B0B1B3",     "B" = "#F18823",     "C" = "#E23130",     "D" = "#1D5D83")  p2 %>% adjust_colors(new_colors) p2 %>% adjust_colors(new_colors, as_palette = TRUE) # new_colors AND new_names  p2 %>%   adjust_labels(treatment, new_names = new_names) %>%    adjust_colors(new_colors, saturation = 0.3) p2 %>%    adjust_colors(new_colors, saturation = 0.3) %>%    adjust_labels(treatment, new_names = new_names) # add_heatmap()  gene_expression %>%    tidyplot(x = sample, y = external_gene_name, color = expression) %>%    add_heatmap() %>%    adjust_size(height = 90) gene_expression %>%    tidyplot(x = sample, y = external_gene_name, color = expression) %>%    add_heatmap(scale = "row") %>%    adjust_labels(external_gene_name, sort_by = -dplyr::desc(direction)) %>%   adjust_size(height = 90) gene_expression %>%    tidyplot(x = sample, y = external_gene_name, color = expression) %>%    add_heatmap(scale = "row", rasterize = TRUE, rasterize_dpi = 20) %>%    adjust_labels(external_gene_name, sort_by = -dplyr::desc(direction)) %>%   adjust_size(height = 90) gene_expression %>%    tidyplot(x = sample, y = external_gene_name, color = expression) %>%    add_heatmap(scale = "column") %>%    adjust_size(height = 90) # plotmath expressions  p2 %>% adjust_x_axis(title = "$Domino~E==m*c^{2}$") p2 %>% adjust_y_axis(title = "$Domino~E==m*c^{2}$") # next chapter  study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter(rasterize = TRUE) study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_mean_value() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = group, y = score, color = dose) %>%    add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = group, y = score, color = dose) %>%    add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_mean_value() study %>%    tidyplot(x = group, y = score, color = dose, dodge_width = 0.6) %>%    add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_mean_value() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_bar(width = 0.02) %>%    add_mean_dot() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_bar(width = 0.02) %>%    add_mean_dot() %>%    add_mean_value(vjust = -1, padding_top = 0.2) study %>%    tidyplot(x = group, y = score, color = dose) %>%    add_mean_bar(width = 0.02) %>%    add_mean_dot() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_range() %>%    add_mean_dot() # box and violin  study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_range() %>%    add_mean_dash() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_box() study %>%    tidyplot(x = dose, y = score, color = group) %>%    add_box() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_violin() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = dose, y = score, color = group) %>%    add_violin() %>%    add_jitter() # adjust_size  p1 p1 %>% adjust_size(width = 70) p1 %>% adjust_size(width = 44, height = 25) p1 %>% adjust_size(width = NA, height = NA) # line plots  study %>%    tidyplot(x = group, y = score, group = participant, color = dose) %>%    add_line() %>%    add_area(alpha = 0.1) # summary lines  study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score) %>%    add_mean_line() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score) %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_mean_dot() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score) %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_mean_dot() %>%    add_error() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score) %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score) %>%    add_error_ribbon() %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score) %>%    add_range_ribbon() %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score) %>%    add_sd_ribbon() %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score) %>%    add_ci95_ribbon() %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score) %>%    add_curve() %>%    add_jitter() # grouped line  study %>%    tidyplot(x = dose, y = score, color = group) %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = dose, y = score, color = group) %>%    add_error_ribbon() %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = dose, y = score, color = group, dodge_width = 0) %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() study %>%    tidyplot(x = dose, y = score, color = group, dodge_width = 0) %>%    add_error_ribbon() %>%    add_mean_line() %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() # apparently there can be no lines between doged data points with the same x axis label # because they need to be in a different aes(group) to be dodged AND they need to in the same aes(group) to be connected by a geom_line() # solution: bring them to different x axis labels  study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = group) %>%    add_line(group = participant, dodge_width = 0, color = "grey") %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_points() study %>%   tidyplot(treatment, score, color = group) %>%   add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%   add_error() %>%   add_points() %>%   add_line(group = participant, dodge_width = 0, color = "grey") %>%   adjust_labels(treatment, sort_by = dose) # proportions  animals %>%    tidyplot(x = diet, color = family) %>%    add_barstack_absolute() animals %>%    tidyplot(x = number_of_legs, color = family) %>%    add_barstack_relative() animals %>%    tidyplot(x = family, color = number_of_legs) %>%    add_barstack_relative() animals %>%    tidyplot(color = diet) %>%    add_donut() animals %>%    tidyplot(color = activity) %>%    add_donut() animals %>%    tidyplot(color = number_of_legs) %>%    add_donut() # spendings  spendings %>%    tidyplot(color = category) %>%    add_donut() spendings %>%    tidyplot(y = amount, color = category) %>%    add_barstack_absolute() spendings %>%    tidyplot(x = category, y = amount, color = category) %>%    add_sum_bar() %>%    add_sum_value(accuracy = 1) %>%    adjust_x_axis(rotate_labels = TRUE) spendings %>%    tidyplot(x = date, y = amount, color = category) %>%    add_sum_dot() %>%    add_sum_value(accuracy = 1, vjust = -1.2) spendings %>%    dplyr::mutate(cum_amount = cumsum(amount)) %>%    tidyplot(x = date, y = cum_amount) %>%    add_line() %>%    add_points() spendings %>%    dplyr::mutate(cum_amount = cumsum(amount)) %>%    tidyplot(x = date, y = cum_amount) %>%    add_area(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_points() spendings %>%    dplyr::mutate(cum_amount = cumsum(amount), .by = category) %>%    tidyplot(x = date, y = cum_amount, color = category, dodge_width = 0) %>%    add_area(alpha = 0.3) spendings %>%    tidyr::complete(date, category, fill = list(title = NA, amount = 0)) %>%    dplyr::mutate(cum_amount = cumsum(amount), .by = category) %>%    tidyplot(x = date, y = cum_amount, color = category, dodge_width = 0) %>%    add_area(alpha = 0.3) spendings %>%    tidyr::complete(date, category, fill = list(title = NA, amount = 0)) %>%    dplyr::mutate(cum_amount = cumsum(amount), .by = category) %>%    tidyplot(x = date, y = cum_amount, color = category, dodge_width = 0) %>%    add_areastack_absolute(alpha = 0.3) # subset data  study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_points() study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_points(data = filter_rows(treatment == "C")) study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_points(data = max_rows(score, n = 1, by = treatment)) # adjust_description  p1 %>% add_title(title = "New title") # add stats  p2 p2 %>% add_stats_pvalue(ref.group = 1) p2 %>% add_stats_pvalue(ref.group = 1, p.adjust.method = "bonferroni") p2 %>% add_stats_asterisks(ref.group = 1, p.adjust.method = "bonferroni") # grouped  p3 <-    study %>%    tidyplot(x = dose, y = score, color = group) %>%    add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter()  p3 p3 %>% add_stats_pvalue() p3 %>% add_stats_pvalue(p.adjust.method = "bonferroni") p3 %>% add_stats_asterisks(p.adjust.method = "bonferroni") # animals  animals %>%   tidyplot(x = family) %>%   add_count_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_count_value(accuracy = 1) %>%    add_count_dash() animals %>%   tidyplot(x = family, y = weight) %>%   add_sum_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_sum_value() %>%    add_sum_dash() animals %>%   tidyplot(x = family, y = weight) %>%   add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%   add_mean_value() animals %>%   tidyplot(x = family, y = weight) %>%   add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%   add_mean_value(vjust = 0.4, hjust = -0.2, padding_top = 0.3) %>%   adjust_flip() animals %>%   tidyplot(x = family, y = speed) %>%   add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%   add_error() %>%   add_jitter() %>%   adjust_x_axis(rotate_labels = TRUE) # split_plot  gene_expression %>%    tidyplot(x = condition, y = expression, color = sample_type) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() %>%    adjust_x_axis(title = "") %>%    split_plot(by = external_gene_name, ncol = 4, nrow = 4) gene_expression %>%    tidyplot(x = condition, y = expression, color = sample_type) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() %>%    adjust_x_axis(title = "") %>%    split_plot(by = external_gene_name, ncol = 4, nrow = 4, widths = 15, heights = 15) gene_expression %>%    tidyplot(x = condition, y = expression, color = sample_type) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() %>%    adjust_x_axis(title = "") %>%    split_plot(by = external_gene_name, ncol = 4, nrow = 4, widths = NA, heights = NA) # stats with split_plot  gene_expression %>%    tidyplot(x = condition, y = expression, color = sample_type) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() %>%    add_stats_pvalue(include_info = FALSE) %>%    adjust_x_axis(title = "") %>%    split_plot(by = external_gene_name, ncol = 4, nrow = 4, widths = 25, heights = 25) gene_expression %>%    tidyplot(x = condition, y = expression, color = sample_type) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() %>%    add_stats_asterisks(include_info = FALSE) %>%    adjust_x_axis(title = "") %>%    split_plot(by = external_gene_name, ncol = 4, nrow = 4, widths = 25, heights = 25) # save_plot  gene_expression %>%    tidyplot(x = condition, y = expression, color = sample_type) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter() %>%    adjust_x_axis(title = "") %>%    split_plot(by = external_gene_name, ncol = 4, nrow = 4) %>%   save_plot(filename = "test_multipage.pdf")  # save intermediate plots  study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_dash() %>%    save_plot(filename = "test1.pdf") %>%   add_error() %>%    save_plot(filename = "test2.pdf") %>%    add_jitter() %>%    save_plot(filename = "test3.pdf")

title: Authors and Citation
text: Engler J (2024). tidyplots: Tidy Plots Using Pipe. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://jbengler.github.io/tidyplots/, https://github.com/jbengler/tidyplots.
code: @Manual{,   title = {tidyplots: Tidy Plots Using the Pipe},   author = {Jan Broder Engler},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://jbengler.github.io/tidyplots/},   url = {https://github.com/jbengler/tidyplots}, }

title: Tidy Plots Using the Pipe
text: tidyplots opinionated plotting package makes ridiculously simple create ready--use plots scientific papers. works gradually adding adjusting plot components provides full control composition, style, absolute sizes. tidyplots powered pipe %>% provides clean minimalist interface commonly used scientific plotting routines.

title: Tidy Plots Using the Pipe
text: can install development version tidyplots GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("jbengler/tidyplots")

title: Tidy Plots Using the Pipe
text: basic example shows solve common problem:
code: library(tidyplots)  study %>%    tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%    add_mean_bar(alpha = 0.3) %>%    add_error() %>%    add_jitter()

what: Add ggplot2 code to your tidyplot — add
title: Add ggplot2 code to your tidyplot — add
Add ggplot2 code to your tidyplot — add
code: add()

title: Add ggplot2 code to your tidyplot — add
code: study %>%   tidyplot(x = treatment, y = score, color = treatment) %>%   add(ggplot2::geom_point()) #> ✔ adjust_size: width = 50 mm, height = 50 mm #> ✔ adjust_x_axis: discrete #> ✔ adjust_y_axis: continuous #> ✔ adjust_colors: applied tidyplots default colors

title: Add statistics — add_stats_pvalue
code: add_stats_pvalue(   gg,   padding_top = 0.15,   method = "t.test",   p.adjust.method = "none",   ref.group = NULL,   label = "{format_p_value(p.adj, 0.0001)}",   label.size = 7/ggplot2::.pt,   step.increase = 0.25,   vjust = -0.25,   bracket.nudge.y = 0.15,   hide.ns = FALSE,   p.adjust.by = "panel",   symnum.args = list(cutpoints = c(0, 0.001, 0.01, 0.05, Inf), symbols = c("***", "**",     "*", "ns")),   include_info = TRUE,   ... )  add_stats_asterisks(   gg,   padding_top = 0.1,   method = "t.test",   p.adjust.method = "none",   ref.group = NULL,   label = "p.adj.signif",   label.size = 10/ggplot2::.pt,   step.increase = 0.2,   vjust = 0.3,   bracket.nudge.y = 0.15,   hide.ns = TRUE,   p.adjust.by = "panel",   symnum.args = list(cutpoints = c(0, 0.001, 0.01, 0.05, Inf), symbols = c("***", "**",     "*", "ns")),   include_info = TRUE,   ... )

title: Add statistics — add_stats_pvalue
text: gg bla padding_top bla method character string indicating method used pairwise comparisons. Default "wilcox_test". Allowed methods include pairwise comparisons methods implemented rstatix R package. methods : "wilcox_test", "t_test", "sign_test", "dunn_test", "emmeans_test", "tukey_hsd", "games_howell_test". p.adjust.method method adjusting p values (see p.adjust).  impact situation, multiple pairwise tests performed; multiple grouping variables. Ignored specified method "tukey_hsd" "games_howell_test" come internal p adjustment method. Allowed values include "holm", "hochberg", "hommel", "bonferroni", "BH", "", "fdr", "none". want adjust p value (recommended), use p.adjust.method = "none". ref.group character string numeric value specifying  reference group. specified, given grouping variable,  group levels compared reference group (.e. control group). ref.group can also "". case,  grouping variable levels compared (.e. basemean). Allowed values can : numeric value: specifying  rank reference group. example, use ref.group = 1  first group reference; use ref.group = 2 second  group reference, . works situations, including  ) comparisons performed x-axis groups ii)  comparisons performed legend groups. character  value: example, can use ref.group = "ctrl" instead using  numeric rank value "ctrl" group. "":  case, grouping variable levels compared (.e.  basemean). label character string specifying label. Can : column containing label (e.g.: label = "p" label = "p.adj"), p p-value. possible values "p.signif", "p.adj.signif", "p.format", "p.adj.format". expression can formatted glue() package. example, specifying label = "Wilcoxon, p = \{p\}", expression {p} replaced value. combination plotmath expressions glue expressions. may want statistical parameter italic; example:label = "Wilcoxon, italic(p)= {p}" . label.size change size label text step.increase numeric vector increase fraction total height every additional comparison minimize overlap. vjust move text relative bracket. bracket.nudge.y Vertical adjustment nudge brackets (fraction total height). Useful move move bracket. positive value, brackets moved ; negative value, brackets moved . hide.ns can logical value (TRUE FALSE) character vector ("p.adj" "p"). p.adjust.possible value one c("group", "panel"). Default "group": grouped data, pairwise test performed, p-values adjusted group level independently. P-values adjusted panel p.adjust.= "panel". symnum.args list arguments pass function  symnum symbolic number coding p-values.  example, symnum.args <- list(cutpoints = c(0, 0.0001, 0.001, 0.01,  0.05, Inf), symbols = c("****", "***", "**", "*",  "ns")). words, use following convention symbols indicating  statistical significance: ns: p > 0.05 *: p <= 0.05 **: p <= 0.01 ***: p <= 0.001 ****:  p <= 0.0001 include_info bla ... bla

title: Subset data — all_rows
code: all_rows()  filter_rows(..., .by = NULL)  max_rows(order_by, n, by = NULL, with_ties = TRUE, na_rm = FALSE)  min_rows(order_by, n, by = NULL, with_ties = TRUE, na_rm = FALSE)  first_rows(n, by = NULL)  last_rows(n, by = NULL)

title: Subset data — all_rows
text: ... <data-masking> Expressions return logical value, defined terms variables .data. multiple expressions included, combined & operator. rows conditions evaluate TRUE kept. .,  <tidy-select> Optionally, selection columns group just operation, functioning alternative group_by(). details examples, see ?dplyr_by. order_by <data-masking> Variable function variables order . order multiple variables, wrap data frame tibble. n number rows select. supplied, n = 1 used. n greater number rows group, result silently truncated group size. negative value n subtracted group size. example, n = -2 group 5 rows select 5 - 2 = 3 rows. with_ties ties kept together? default, TRUE, may return rows request. Use FALSE ignore ties, return first n rows. na_rm missing values order_by removed result? FALSE, NA values sorted end (like arrange()), included insufficient non-missing values reach n.

what: Format numbers and p values — format_number
title: Format numbers and p values — format_number
Format numbers and p values — format_number
code: format_number(x, accuracy = 0.1, big.mark = ",", scale_cut = NULL, ...)  format_p_value(x, accuracy = 1e-04)

title: Format numbers and p values — format_number
text: x bla accuracy number round . Use (e.g.) 0.01 show 2 decimal places precision. NULL, default, uses heuristic ensure breaks minimum number digits needed show difference adjacent values. Applied rescaled data. big.mark Character used every 3 digits separate thousands. scale_cut Named numeric vector allows rescale large (small) numbers add prefix. Built-helpers include: cut_short_scale(): [10^3, 10^6) = K, [10^6, 10^9) = M, [10^9, 10^12) = B, [10^12, Inf) = T. cut_long_scale(): [10^3, 10^6) = K, [10^6, 10^12) = M, [10^12, 10^18) = B, [10^18, Inf) = T. cut_si(unit): uses standard SI units. supply vector c(= 100, b = 1000), absolute values range [0, 100) rescaled, absolute values range [100, 1000) divided 100 given suffix "", absolute values range [1000, Inf) divided 1000 given suffix "b". ... Arguments passed scales::number scale scaling factor: x multiplied scale formatting. useful underlying data small large. style_positive string determines style positive numbers: "none" (default): change, e.g. 1. "plus": preceded +, e.g. +1. style_negative string determines style negative numbers: "hyphen" (default): preceded standard hypen -, e.g. -1. "minus", uses proper Unicode minus symbol. typographical nicety ensures - aligns horizontal bar horizontal bar +. "parens", wrapped parentheses, e.g. (1).

title: Save plot to file — save_plot
text: function takes ggplot list ggplots writes (multipage) file. See details.

title: Save plot to file — save_plot
code: save_plot(   gg = last_plot(),   filename,   device = NULL,   path = NULL,   scale = 1,   width = NA,   height = NA,   units = c("mm", "cm", "in"),   dpi = 300,   limitsize = TRUE,   return_input = TRUE,   multiple_files = FALSE,   bg = "transparent",   ... )

title: Save plot to file — save_plot
text: gg ggplot list ggplots filename File name create disk. device Device use. Can either device function (e.g. png), one "eps", "ps", "tex" (pictex), "pdf", "jpeg", "tiff", "png", "bmp", "svg" "wmf" (windows ). path Path directory save plot : path filename combined create fully qualified file name. Defaults working directory. scale Multiplicative scaling factor. width, height Dimensions saved plot. specified, save_multipage() try infer dimensions incoming ggplot object. incoming ggplot object absolute dimensions, system default device dimensions used. units Unit dimensions. Defaults "mm". dpi Plot resolution. Also accepts string input: "retina" (320), "print" (300), "screen" (72). Applies raster output types. limitsize TRUE (default), ggsave() save images larger 50x50 inches, prevent common error specifying dimensions pixels. return_input Return input ggplot plotlist saving. enables use within dplyr pipes. multiple_files Save pages individal files. bg Background colour. NULL, uses plot.background fill value plot theme. ... arguments passed graphics device function, specified device.

title: Save plot to file — save_plot
text: Handling multiple pages. list ggplots, list element rendered separate page mutipage pdf file. save pages individual files, use multiple_files = TRUE. output formats support multipage files (png, jpg, etc), pages saved individual files default. Handling file dimensions. Output file dimensions determined according following precedence. width height parameters save_multipage(). Dimensions inferred incoming ggplot object containing absolute dimensions. System default device dimensions.

title: Split plot into subplots — split_plot
code: split_plot(   gg,   by,   ncol = NULL,   nrow = NULL,   byrow = NULL,   widths = 30,   heights = 25,   guides = "collect",   tag_level = NULL,   design = NULL,   unit = "mm" )

title: Split plot into subplots — split_plot
text: gg ggplot Variable used faceting. ncol, nrow number columns rows per page. byrow Analogous byrow matrix(). FALSE plots filled column-major order widths, heights relative widths heights column row grid. get repeated match dimensions grid. special value NA/-1null behave 1null unless fixed aspect plot inserted case allow dimension expand contract match aspect ratio content guides string specifying guides treated layout. 'collect' collect guides given nesting level, removing duplicates. 'keep' stop collection level let guides placed alongside plot. auto allow guides collected upper level tries, place alongside plot .  modify default guide "position" theme(legend.position=...) also collecting guides must apply change overall patchwork (see example). tag_level string ('keep' 'new') indicate auto-tagging behave. See plot_annotation(). design Specification location areas layout. Can either specified text string concatenating calls area() together. See examples information use. unit Unit length. Defaults "mm".
